item.title: Elixir Many to Many Inserts
item.description:
The Ecto docs explain how to set up many to many relationships in your database. They even explain how to seamlessly update many to many records in your Phoenix UI:

<%= form_for @todo_list_changeset,
             todo_list_path(@conn, :create),
             fn f -> %>
  <%= text_input f, :title %>
  <%= inputs_for f, :todo_items, fn i -> %>
    ...
  <% end %>
<% end %>

Here, we have a form that allows you to update many todo items at once, and Ecto handles all the details. This is great if all you need to do is update existing records. However, adding new records can be a bit trickier, and the solution isn’t quite as automatic. Here is how you can do it.

def create_todo_item(%{params: %{"list_id" => id}} = conn, %{"todo_item" => todo_item_params}) do
  todo_item = Ecto.Changeset.change(todo_item_params)
  list = MyApp.get_list!(id)

  items = list.items ++ [todo_item]
              |> Enum.map(&Ecto.Changeset.change/1)

  case list
  |> Ecto.Changeset.change
  |> Ecto.Changeset.put_assoc(:items, items)
  |> MyApp.Repo.update 
end

This will automatically create a new row in the ‘todo_item’ table, as well as the association table ‘todo_item_list’.

item.title: Rendering Javascript Charts in Elixir
item.description:
If you’re like me, you like to stay away from Javascript when writing your Elixir code. That is why I was pleased to discover chartkick-ex recently when I needed a chart solution for my Phoenix site. It makes embedding Javascript charts in to your Elixir templates a breeze.

To install it, just add the following to your mix.exs file

[
...
{:chartkick, "~>0.4.0"},
{:poison, "~> 3.1"}
]

Chartkick can use Google Charts, Chart.js, or Highcharts. So you need to add one of the following to the <head> of your site

<script src="//www.google.com/jsapi"></script>

//or

<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/chart.js@2.9.3/dist/Chart.min.js"></script>

//or

<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/highcharts/8.1.0/highcharts.min.js"></script>

Then, you can use Elixir in your template files to handle the rest.

<% data = Poison.encode!([[175, 60], [190, 80], [180, 75]]) %>
<%= Chartkick.line_chart data %>
